Test Data: Initial page load in a modern desktop browser.
Predicted Outcome: window.mediaData.rawData contains six companies with non empty years arrays and realistic subscriber values.
Actual Outcome: Pending – update with pass/fail and any quirks you notice once you've run this check.
Notes: Good quick sanity check after any major data change or refactor to be sure nothing fundamental broke in the dataset.
Steps: Open the app in the browser; open DevTools console; type window.mediaData.rawData and review its contents.

Test Data: App loaded with no interaction yet.
Predicted Outcome: Each company entry in rawData has a company_name string, a years array, and each year has a quarters array.
Actual Outcome: Pending – confirm structure matches this description once inspected.
Notes: If this structure drifts, a lot of visualization bugs will follow, so it's worth double-checking when you edit the data model.
Steps: In the console inspect window.mediaData.rawData; expand a few company objects and confirm the nested structure matches expectations.

Test Data: Developer calls to mediaUtils.streamToCompany with valid keys HBO HULU AMAZON DISNEY NETFLIX SPOTIFY.
Predicted Outcome: For each valid key the function returns the exact same uppercase string; no null values are returned for these inputs.
Actual Outcome: Pending – after running, note if any mapping is missing or mistyped.
Notes: This function underpins all the charts, so even a small typo here can silently break a specific provider's visuals.
Steps: Open DevTools console; call mediaUtils.streamToCompany for each known symbol; compare outputs with the inputs.

Test Data: Developer calls to mediaUtils.streamToCompany with an unknown key such as FOO.
Predicted Outcome: The function returns null and does not throw any error.
Actual Outcome: Pending – record whether the call safely returns null without noise in the console.
Notes: This is mostly a guardrail check to make sure the app fails gracefully when someone wires a bad symbol.
Steps: In the console call mediaUtils.streamToCompany('FOO'); confirm the result is null and no error appears.

Test Data: Developer calls mediaUtils.extractSeries for a known company for example NETFLIX.
Predicted Outcome: The function returns labels and values arrays of equal length with labels formatted as year and quarter such as 2019 Q4 and values as numbers.
Actual Outcome: Pending – once tested, jot down if label formatting or lengths look off.
Notes: A mismatch here will lead directly to broken lines or misaligned tooltips, so it's worth being precise.
Steps: In the console call mediaUtils.extractSeries('NETFLIX'); check that labels and values align and that the label format looks consistent.

Test Data: Developer calls mediaUtils.extractSeries with a non existent company name such as FOO.
Predicted Outcome: The function returns an object with empty labels and values arrays and does not log any errors.
Actual Outcome: Pending – confirm the function behaves quietly and predictably in this case.
Notes: This helps make sure future code that calls extractSeries defensively won't blow up on unknown inputs.
Steps: Call mediaUtils.extractSeries('FOO') in the console; verify both arrays are empty and no error is thrown.

Test Data: Fresh page load on desktop with no logos selected and default Line Chart active.
Predicted Outcome: The comparison area shows the empty state message and illustration; no chart data is drawn; comparison area does not have the has-data class.
Actual Outcome: Pending – after loading, mark here whether the empty state looked correct on your machine.
Notes: This is the baseline user experience, so if this feels confusing or broken it's worth revisiting the copy and visuals.
Steps: Open the app; scroll to the comparison section; visually confirm the empty state and check the element classes with DevTools.

Test Data: Clicking the NETFLIX logo button once from the initial state.
Predicted Outcome: NETFLIX becomes selected and its logo button gains the active class and glow effect; selectedStreams now contains NETFLIX; the empty state hides and the line chart renders NETFLIX data.
Actual Outcome: Pending – note whether the visual feedback and chart update feel snappy or laggy.
Notes: This is a core interaction, so pay attention to how responsive and satisfying it feels, not just whether it technically works.
Steps: Click the NETFLIX logo; watch for the visual change; open the console to confirm selectedStreams and look at the chart update.

Test Data: Clicking the NETFLIX logo button a second time after it is already active.
Predicted Outcome: NETFLIX is removed from selectedStreams and its button loses the active class; if no other services are selected the empty state reappears in the comparison area.
Actual Outcome: Pending – confirm that toggling off works cleanly and log any flicker or delay you see.
Notes: Users often change their minds, so this off state should feel as polished as turning things on.
Steps: Activate NETFLIX then click it again; confirm the glow and active styling disappear and the empty prompt is shown if it is the only selection.

Test Data: Dragging the HBO logo into the comparison area drop zone from the popular section.
Predicted Outcome: HBO is added to selectedStreams and its button becomes active; the chart for the current visualization updates to include HBO; console logs show HBO in the selected set.
Actual Outcome: Pending – record whether drag and drop feels natural and whether the drop zone reacts the way you expect.
Notes: If this interaction feels fiddly, consider adding hover feedback or snapping so it's harder to miss the target.
Steps: Click and drag the HBO logo over the comparison area; drop it; watch the visual feedback and inspect the console output.

Test Data: Using the search bar by typing a partial match such as net into the input.
Predicted Outcome: The search results box displays a clickable result button labeled NETFLIX and the placeholder text is replaced by real content.
Actual Outcome: Pending – capture whether search feels responsive and whether the result appears quickly enough.
Notes: If there's noticeable lag, it might be worth debouncing or trimming the search logic a bit.
Steps: Type net in the search box; observe the searchResults container and confirm a NETFLIX button appears.

Test Data: Clicking a search result button such as NETFLIX after typing in the search box.
Predicted Outcome: The corresponding stream is added to selectedStreams and the search result button toggles to an active look; the associated logo button also becomes active and charts update to include that stream.
Actual Outcome: Pending – after trying this, jot down whether the cross highlighting between search and logos worked as expected.
Notes: This flow bridges the search UI and the main selection controls, so consistency really matters here.
Steps: Type net; click the NETFLIX search result; verify both the result and the main logo show active styling and that the chart redraws with NETFLIX data.

Test Data: Clearing the search input back to an empty string after previously typing some text.
Predicted Outcome: The search results list is cleared or only shows the placeholder message and no stale entries remain; no errors occur during typing or clearing.
Actual Outcome: Pending – confirm the results area resets nicely and note any odd flicker or left over buttons.
Notes: Search UIs often feel sticky if old results hang around, so this is mostly a polish check.
Steps: Type a few letters that produce results; then delete them until the input is empty; watch the searchResults area for correct clearing behavior.

Test Data: Switching between visualization type buttons for example from Line Chart to Bubble Chart to Area Chart to Heat Map while at least one stream is selected.
Predicted Outcome: Only the chosen chart container is visible at a time with display block and the others are hidden; the active button styling follows the selected chart; the underlying data stays consistent.
Actual Outcome: Pending – once you've tried this, note if any chart lags behind or fails to update.
Notes: This is a high level smoke test that the whole visualization toggle concept feels cohesive.
Steps: Select a couple of services; click each viz-option button in turn; confirm only the matching chart canvas shows and the visual style of the selected button updates correctly.

Test Data: Resizing the browser window to a width below 768 pixels to simulate tablet or small laptop.
Predicted Outcome: The layout becomes vertical with the sidebar stacking on top; charts shrink in height but remain readable; nothing overlaps or overflows awkwardly.
Actual Outcome: Pending – add comments here if any layout breakpoint felt awkward or cramped.
Notes: This check helps you catch mobile and tablet layout issues before they surprise real users.
Steps: Open the app; gradually narrow the browser window below 768 pixels; check the sidebar position chart sizing and overall layout responsiveness.

Test Data: Selecting only NETFLIX with Line Chart active on a desktop screen.
Predicted Outcome: The main line chart displays a single red line for NETFLIX with chronological labels from the earliest NETFLIX data through the latest; tooltips show values in millions when hovering.
Actual Outcome: Pending – verify the line and tooltips match expectations and mention any small visual oddities.
Notes: This is the simplest single series slice of the product and should feel very clean and readable.
Steps: Activate only the NETFLIX logo; hover along the line; confirm the labels ordering and tooltip content.

Test Data: Selecting multiple services such as NETFLIX AMAZON and DISNEY while viewing the line chart.
Predicted Outcome: Each service appears as its own colored line that follows the combined timeline; the legend lists all selected companies; missing quarters are handled smoothly without broken visuals thanks to spanGaps.
Actual Outcome: Pending – record whether all lines and legend entries matched the selected set.
Notes: Pay attention to color contrast and line overlap here since it directly affects how legible comparisons are.
Steps: Activate NETFLIX AMAZON and DISNEY; observe the chart; compare line colors against companyColors and verify the legend cross references.

Test Data: Clearing all selections while the line chart is visible.
Predicted Outcome: The line chart removes all datasets and labels; any mini range chart shows no data; the comparison area goes back to the empty state view.
Actual Outcome: Pending – make a quick note if anything remained on screen after clearing.
Notes: This is a good way to surface state management bugs where chart data hangs around longer than it should.
Steps: Select one or more services; then deselect all of them; confirm the line disappears and the empty state returns without errors.

Test Data: Having at least one service selected so the range selector should appear below the main line chart.
Predicted Outcome: The rangeSelector container shows a mini line chart of all selected data and a draggable window with handles and shaded side masks.
Actual Outcome: Pending – confirm the mini chart appears and feels roughly aligned with the main chart.
Notes: If this mini view feels confusing, you may want to add labels or a short hint in the UI later.
Steps: Enable a few services; scroll below the main line chart; verify the small overview chart and the draggable selection window are present.

Test Data: Dragging the center of the range window left or right to focus on a different time slice.
Predicted Outcome: The main line chart smoothly updates its x axis to show only the portion of the timeline within the selected window while the mini chart remains unchanged.
Actual Outcome: Pending – once tried, log whether the motion and redraw feel smooth enough.
Notes: This is a UI affordance that can easily feel jumpy, so it's useful to pay attention to perceived smoothness here.
Steps: With multiple years visible click and drag the interior of the range window; watch the main chart labels and lines adjust as you move the window.

Test Data: Dragging the left and right handles of the range window inward to narrow the visible time range.
Predicted Outcome: The main chart zooms into the chosen date range and its axes rescale appropriately without visual glitches or console errors.
Actual Outcome: Pending – capture whether the handles respected reasonable minimum widths and stayed within bounds.
Notes: Edge cases around min and max zoom are common spots for off by one bugs or awkward behaviour.
Steps: Grab the left handle drag it inward; then adjust the right handle; confirm that only the desired segment of the time axis appears in the main line chart.

Test Data: Viewing event markers with NETFLIX and DISNEY selected around key dates such as 2007 Q1 and 2019 Q4.
Predicted Outcome: Vertical colored marker lines appear at those dates with small dots at the top; hovering shows a short tooltip naming the event and date.
Actual Outcome: Pending – after testing, note if markers lined up with the expected dates.
Notes: These markers are a nice storytelling detail, so it's worth confirming they feel trustworthy.
Steps: Activate NETFLIX and DISNEY; look for vertical markers on the timeline; hover near them and read the mini tooltip content.

Test Data: Clicking on an event marker line associated with a known milestone such as the Netflix streaming launch.
Predicted Outcome: A new browser tab opens to an external page for more details about the event while the existing page continues to function normally.
Actual Outcome: Pending – mark whether the external links opened reliably and in a new tab.
Notes: Keep an eye out for pop up blockers or warning messages in your browser as well.
Steps: With the marker visible click directly on the marker line or dot; watch the browser open a new tab and check for any script errors.

Test Data: Selecting only a company that has no configured event markers such as HULU.
Predicted Outcome: No vertical event marker lines are shown on the chart even though HULU data is plotted; the chart remains clean.
Actual Outcome: Pending – confirm no stray markers appeared and the chart looked uncluttered.
Notes: This keeps charts for companies without major events from feeling noisy or inconsistent.
Steps: Activate only HULU; scan the chart for event marker lines; confirm that none are present.

Test Data: Switching to Area Chart when no streams are selected.
Predicted Outcome: The areaChart canvas loads with a dark background and empty datasets; the range selector for the area view either stays empty or hidden; there are no console errors.
Actual Outcome: Pending – add a quick note if you see any error messages or unexpected UI.
Notes: This is mainly a does nothing weird happen check for the area chart when there's no data.
Steps: Click the Area Chart button while nothing is selected; verify that no colored areas are drawn and that the browser console stays quiet.

Test Data: Switching to Area Chart with several services selected such as NETFLIX SPOTIFY and HULU.
Predicted Outcome: A stacked area chart appears with layers for each company; tooltips show per company subscriber counts and a footer line that gives the total market at each point.
Actual Outcome: Pending – record whether the stack ordering and tooltip totals looked sensible.
Notes: Area charts can be visually busy, so make sure the end result still feels understandable at a glance.
Steps: Activate at least three services; then choose Area Chart; hover over different time points and read the tooltip content.

Test Data: Including a service with sparse quarterly data like HBO in the area chart.
Predicted Outcome: The HBO area does not drop to zero at missing quarters; instead it carries forward the last known value so the stack remains continuous and visually sensible.
Actual Outcome: Pending – confirm the HBO area looks continuous rather than broken.
Notes: If you see sudden drops to zero, it may signal a bug in the carry forward logic.
Steps: Select HBO along with another service; examine the stacked areas where HBO lacks explicit quarters; confirm the shape stays flat rather than disappearing abruptly.

Test Data: Viewing the mini area chart range selector under the main area chart with multiple services chosen.
Predicted Outcome: The areaRangeSelector container appears with a compact stacked area visualization and a draggable window very similar to the line chart range selector.
Actual Outcome: Pending – after using it, note whether the control felt discoverable and useful.
Notes: Because this is a second range UI, consistency with the line chart's version helps users a lot.
Steps: With two or more services selected and Area Chart active scroll below the main area plot; check that a mini chart and its handles are in place.

Test Data: Dragging the area chart range window or its handles to zoom in on part of the timeline.
Predicted Outcome: The main stacked area chart updates to show only labels and data within the chosen range and the effect feels responsive and stable.
Actual Outcome: Pending – jot down if you noticed any lag or visual tearing during the zoom.
Notes: This is especially important on lower end machines where redrawing large stacked areas can be expensive.
Steps: Drag the edges and center of the range window; watch how the main area chart redraws and make sure axes and stacks remain correct.

Test Data: Clearing all selections while the Area Chart is visible.
Predicted Outcome: All area datasets and labels clear out; the mini overview chart is emptied; the comparison area returns to its empty state without script errors.
Actual Outcome: Pending – confirm that both the main and mini charts fully reset.
Notes: If anything remains faintly visible, it might point to a state cleanup issue.
Steps: With Area Chart active deselect every logo; check that the area view resets and that the UI returns to the start prompt.

Test Data: Selecting Bubble Chart with no streams selected at all.
Predicted Outcome: The bubbleChart canvas is visible with a plain dark background; no bubbles are drawn and no animation runs; there are no console warnings.
Actual Outcome: Pending – verify the canvas stays calm and the console is clean.
Notes: Because the bubble chart uses animation, it's important that it sits quietly when there's nothing to show.
Steps: Click the Bubble Chart button with nothing selected; inspect the canvas visually and confirm there are no active bubbles or errors.

Test Data: Selecting only NETFLIX while Bubble Chart is active.
Predicted Outcome: A single red bubble appears sized according to Netflix subscribers; the bubble gently floats in a small circle around its center position; the bubble stays fully within the canvas bounds.
Actual Outcome: Pending – after running, note whether the label and sizing felt right and whether the animation was smooth.
Notes: This is a simple case to gauge whether the sizing formula feels intuitive and the animation is pleasant before adding more bubbles.
Steps: Activate NETFLIX and ensure Bubble Chart is chosen; watch the canvas for one clear bubble that gently floats; confirm it never touches the edges.

Test Data: Selecting all six services while Bubble Chart is active.
Predicted Outcome: Six bubbles appear each with its own color; each bubble floats gently at its own speed in small circles; all bubbles stay within canvas bounds and don't overlap excessively.
Actual Outcome: Pending – record if any bubbles went off screen or if the animation felt too fast or distracting.
Notes: We intentionally have more tests around the bubble chart because animation and positioning can hide subtle issues.
Steps: Turn on AMAZON DISNEY HBO HULU NETFLIX and SPOTIFY; observe the bubble field for a while; confirm all bubbles stay visible and the motion feels natural.

Test Data: Hovering over a bubble without clicking.
Predicted Outcome: The cursor changes to a pointer icon; the hovered bubble stops floating and stays in place; the bubble gains a stronger outline and higher opacity; a tooltip appears showing company details.
Actual Outcome: Pending – confirm the hover state feels clear and responsive and the tooltip shows correct data.
Notes: This small interaction does a lot of work to make the chart feel tactile and explorable.
Steps: Move the mouse slowly across different bubbles; pause over one; confirm the cursor changes, the bubble stops moving, and the tooltip appears.

Test Data: Hovering over a bubble long enough to see the tooltip panel.
Predicted Outcome: A floating tooltip appears near the cursor that shows the company name the most recent subscriber count and the period label formatted neatly.
Actual Outcome: Pending – write down any mismatches you spot between the tooltip and chart data.
Notes: Tooltips are often how people actually read numbers, so accuracy and legibility matter a lot here.
Steps: Hover over a bubble while watching the area around the cursor; read the tooltip text and check that the numbers match the underlying data for that company.

Test Data: Moving the mouse away from a hovered bubble.
Predicted Outcome: The bubble resumes its gentle floating animation; the tooltip disappears; the cursor returns to default; the bubble's visual highlight is removed.
Actual Outcome: Pending – after trying this, note whether the transition back to floating felt smooth.
Notes: This helps confirm that the animation restart logic works correctly and doesn't cause any visual jumps.
Steps: Hover over a bubble; then move the mouse away; watch the bubble start floating again and confirm the tooltip disappears cleanly.

Test Data: Deselecting all services while bubbles are visible and floating.
Predicted Outcome: All bubbles disappear immediately; the animation loop stops so CPU usage remains modest; the canvas shows only the dark background; no ghost tooltips linger.
Actual Outcome: Pending – confirm that animation stopped and that performance looked normal.
Notes: Keep an eye on laptop fans or Task Manager/Activity Monitor if you suspect the loop kept running.
Steps: With several services selected click each logo again to deselect; watch the canvas clear and confirm that no animation or tooltips remain.

Test Data: Resizing the browser window while the bubble chart is running with multiple bubbles floating.
Predicted Outcome: The canvas resizes to match its container; bubbles reposition themselves within the new bounds accounting for their size; all bubbles remain fully visible; the animation continues smoothly.
Actual Outcome: Pending – note whether resizing introduced any jank or visual glitches and whether bubbles stayed properly positioned.
Notes: The bubble chart is more demanding than the others, so this is a good moment to spot layout and performance issues.
Steps: With Bubble Chart visible resize the window wider and narrower; watch how the bubbles adapt to the canvas size and confirm none go off screen.

Test Data: Selecting a single large bubble such as NETFLIX with a high subscriber count.
Predicted Outcome: The bubble is sized appropriately large but still fits comfortably within the canvas with proper margins; the bubble floats without touching edges; text remains readable.
Actual Outcome: Pending – confirm the largest bubbles don't overwhelm the canvas or become unreadable.
Notes: This tests the boundary conditions of the sizing formula and ensures the layout handles edge cases gracefully.
Steps: Activate only NETFLIX which has a high subscriber count; check that the bubble is large but still has space around it and that the text is clear.

Test Data: Selecting multiple bubbles with very different sizes such as a large NETFLIX and a smaller HULU.
Predicted Outcome: Both bubbles are positioned with adequate spacing; the smaller bubble doesn't get hidden behind the larger one; both float independently at their own speeds.
Actual Outcome: Pending – record whether the size differences felt proportional and whether the layout handled the contrast well.
Notes: This checks that the grid positioning logic accounts for varying bubble sizes and doesn't create awkward overlaps.
Steps: Select NETFLIX and HULU together; observe how the different sized bubbles are arranged and whether they both remain clearly visible.

Test Data: Switching to Heat Map view while no services are selected.
Predicted Outcome: The heatmap canvas shows only a dark background and possibly the title area; there are no data rows and no errors are logged.
Actual Outcome: Pending – once tested, confirm there were no stray artifacts.
Notes: This is similar to other empty state checks but for the custom drawn heat map.
Steps: Click the Heat Map visualization option with zero selections; confirm that the chart space remains empty but the app is stable.

Test Data: Selecting a single company such as NETFLIX while Heat Map is active.
Predicted Outcome: One horizontal row of cells is drawn for that company with colors shifting over time to represent growth rates; the title Growth Rate Heat Map appears above.
Actual Outcome: Pending – record whether the color scale and row label felt intuitive.
Notes: This view should make it easy to quickly scan how a single service has been growing over time.
Steps: Turn on NETFLIX and choose Heat Map; inspect the row and title; verify that cell colors tend green when growth is positive and more muted when flat.

Test Data: Selecting several services for example DISNEY NETFLIX and SPOTIFY while viewing the heat map.
Predicted Outcome: Multiple labeled rows appear stacked vertically with a shared timeline; missing data points show as subtle placeholder cells rather than being left blank.
Actual Outcome: Pending – confirm the rows lined up correctly and no labels overlapped.
Notes: If things feel cramped, you might later tweak paddings or font sizes to keep this view readable.
Steps: Select at least three services and stay on Heat Map; scroll through the chart visually and confirm that every company has a labeled row and a continuous grid.

Test Data: Observing numeric growth labels inside cells where there is enough space on a desktop sized window.
Predicted Outcome: Many cells display rounded percentage values in white text centered within the colored background making the growth trend easy to read.
Actual Outcome: Pending – after inspection, note whether the text stayed legible across the chart.
Notes: This is mostly about typography and contrast but has a big effect on usability.
Steps: With the window at a comfortable width inspect a few rows; look for small percentage labels inside larger cells and compare them to the apparent color intensity.

Test Data: Reviewing the legend at the bottom of the heat map.
Predicted Outcome: A gradient bar appears running from a red tone on one side through neutral gray to a green tone on the other with Negative and Positive labels near the ends.
Actual Outcome: Pending – mark whether the legend made the color mapping clear at a glance.
Notes: A clear legend helps new users understand the view without needing extra documentation.
Steps: Scroll down to the bottom of the heatmap area; look at the color bar and confirm the text and gradient direction make sense.

Test Data: Moving the mouse across various heat map cells to trigger tooltips.
Predicted Outcome: A tooltip pops up near the cursor showing the company the quarter label the subscriber count and the growth percentage in a color that matches positive or negative movement.
Actual Outcome: Pending – after trying this, jot down if any tooltips felt misplaced or incorrect.
Notes: This interaction turns the heat map from a broad overview into a detail on demand tool, so it should feel reliable.
Steps: Hover slowly over different cells; watch the tooltip text and color and confirm it disappears when the cursor leaves the cell or canvas.

Test Data: Resizing the window while several companies are displayed in the heat map.
Predicted Outcome: The grid scales to fit the new width and height while cells remain aligned under their labels and tooltips still appear in the right places.
Actual Outcome: Pending – confirm alignment held up after resizing.
Notes: Pay attention to whether labels drift relative to cells since that can be disorienting.
Steps: With three or more companies active adjust the browser width; verify that the matrix keeps its structure and interaction still works.

Test Data: Switching among Line Bubble Area and Heat Map visualizations when no companies are selected.
Predicted Outcome: Each chart view appears with its base canvas and styling but none of them attempts to plot data; the empty state stays visible and there are no script errors.
Actual Outcome: Pending – record whether any chart misbehaved in this all empty scenario.
Notes: This is a broad smoke test for switching states without any selected data.
Steps: Starting from a fresh load click each visualization button in turn without selecting any logos; watch each canvas and the empty state behavior.

Test Data: Selecting all six companies and rapidly switching between chart types.
Predicted Outcome: Every visualization updates to show all six datasets or bubbles or rows without crashing; performance remains acceptable and tooltips continue to feel snappy.
Actual Outcome: Pending – after doing this, note any lag or memory issues you experienced.
Notes: This is intentionally a bit of a stress test to flush out heavier performance issues.
Steps: Activate all logos then click through Line Bubble Area and Heat Map several times; observe responsiveness and look at the console for any warnings.

Test Data: Typing a query that matches no company names such as xyz in the search box.
Predicted Outcome: The search results area shows no company buttons and does not throw any errors; placeholder or empty state text is shown appropriately.
Actual Outcome: Pending – confirm the empty results state looked reasonable.
Notes: You might later refine the copy here if it feels unclear to users.
Steps: Enter xyz into the search field; inspect the searchResults panel and confirm that nothing unexpected appears.

Test Data: Rapidly toggling the same logo button on and off many times in a row for example NETFLIX.
Predicted Outcome: The active styling and selectedStreams set stay in sync with the last click; charts update correctly; there are no stuck states or flickering artifacts.
Actual Outcome: Pending – note whether any weird intermediate states showed up while you were clicking quickly.
Notes: This helps catch subtle race conditions or DOM update timing issues.
Steps: Click the same logo at least ten times in quick succession; after you finish check the final visual state and the console log of selectedStreams.

Test Data: Leaving the mouse cursor over a bubble for an extended period while it's floating.
Predicted Outcome: The bubble stops floating and stays stable under the cursor; the tooltip remains visible and readable; no performance degradation occurs.
Actual Outcome: Pending – confirm the hover state remains stable and doesn't cause any issues over time.
Notes: This checks that the animation pause logic works correctly and doesn't leak resources.
Steps: Hover over a bubble and leave your mouse there for 30 seconds; confirm it stays still and the tooltip doesn't flicker or disappear.

Test Data: Switching from Bubble Chart to another chart type while bubbles are actively floating.
Predicted Outcome: The bubble animation stops cleanly; the new chart type renders correctly; no animation frames continue running in the background.
Actual Outcome: Pending – verify that switching away stops the animation loop and doesn't leave any lingering processes.
Notes: This is important for performance since animation loops can drain battery if they don't stop properly.
Steps: With bubbles floating switch to Line Chart; check the console and Task Manager to confirm the animation stopped.

Test Data: Selecting bubbles and then resizing the window to a very small width such as mobile size.
Predicted Outcome: Bubbles reposition themselves to fit the smaller canvas; all bubbles remain visible with proper spacing; text stays readable if possible.
Actual Outcome: Pending – note whether the mobile layout felt cramped or if bubbles became too small to read.
Notes: Mobile responsiveness is crucial, so this edge case helps catch layout issues on small screens.
Steps: With multiple bubbles selected resize the window to 400 pixels wide; check that bubbles adapt and remain usable.
